threats.title: Spoofing the Generic External Interactor External Entity
threats.description: External NSILI Client may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to NSILI App Endpoint. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: The NSIL interface assumes that servers and clients are installed on System High networks with network and workstation protections appropriate to the classification level of the network. It is assumed that all information loaded into an NSI library is authorized for access by all users authorized for the network.

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for NSILI App
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against NSILI App Endpoint or an elevation of privilege attack against NSILI App Endpoint or an information disclosure by NSILI App Endpoint. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including the NSILI Endpoint.

threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by NSILI App
threats.description: NSILI App Endpoint claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: The NSILI App is a trusted process/entity and errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Request may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: The NSIL interface assumes that servers and clients are installed on System High networks with network and workstation protections appropriate to the classification level of the network. It is assumed that all information loaded into an NSI library is authorized for access by all users authorized for the network.

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for NSILI App
threats.description: NSILI App Endpoint crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: If the NSILI App Endpoint crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Data Flow Generic Data Flow Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: Errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities. If the NSILI App Endpoint crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: NSILI App Endpoint may be able to impersonate the context of External NSILI Client in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: The NSILI App Endpoint is a trusted process/entity and will not attack the client(s). Authentication options are available for verification of legitimacy/identity.

threats.title: NSILI App May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: External NSILI Client may be able to remotely execute code for NSILI App Endpoint.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including App Endpoints.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in NSILI App
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into NSILI App Endpoint in order to change the flow of program execution within NSILI App Endpoint to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: The NSILI App always runs at the same execution level, so changing program flow would not gain an attacker additional privileges.

threats.title: Cross Site Request Forgery
threats.description: Cross-site request forgery (CSRF or XSRF) is a type of attack in which an attacker forces a user's browser to make a forged request to a vulnerable site by exploiting an existing trust relationship between the browser and the vulnerable web site.  In a simple scenario, a user is logged in to web site A using a cookie as a credential.  The other browses to web site B.  Web site B returns a page with a hidden form that posts to web site A.  Since the browser will carry the user's cookie to web site A, web site B now can take any action on web site A, for example, adding an admin to an account.  The attack can be used to exploit any requests that the browser automatically authenticates, e.g. by session cookie, integrated authentication, IP whitelisting, â€¦  The attack can be carried out in many ways such as by luring the victim to a site under control of the attacker, getting the user to click a link in a phishing email, or hacking a reputable web site that the victim will visit. The issue can only be resolved on the server side by requiring that all authenticated state-changing requests include an additional piece of secret payload (canary or CSRF token) which is known only to the legitimate web site and the browser and which is protected in transit through SSL/TLS. See the Forgery Protection property on the flow stencil for a list of mitigations.
threats.mitigation: The NSIL interface assumes that servers and clients are installed on System High networks with network and workstation protections appropriate to the classification level of the network. It is assumed that all information loaded into an NSI library is authorized for access by all users authorized for the network.

threats.title: Spoofing the NSILI App Process
threats.description: NSILI App Endpoint may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by External NSILI Client. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: The NSIL interface assumes that servers and clients are installed on System High networks with network and workstation protections appropriate to the classification level of the network. It is assumed that all information loaded into an NSI library is authorized for access by all users authorized for the network.

threats.title: Spoofing of the Generic External Interactor External Destination Entity
threats.description: External NSILI Client may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of External NSILI Client. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: The NSIL interface assumes that servers and clients are installed on System High networks with network and workstation protections appropriate to the classification level of the network. It is assumed that all information loaded into an NSI library is authorized for access by all users authorized for the network.

threats.title: External Entity Generic External Interactor Potentially Denies Receiving Data
threats.description: External NSILI Client claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: The DDF Catalog runs on the same system as the NSILI App Endpoint.

threats.title: Data Flow Generic Data Flow Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: If the NSILI App Endpoint crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: DDF Catalog may be able to impersonate the context of NSILI App Endpoint in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog runs on the same system as the NSILI App.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: NSILI App Endpoint may be able to impersonate the context of DDF Catalog in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: NSILI App Endpoint is a trusted process/entity and will not attack the client(s).

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: NSILI Source may be able to impersonate the context of DDF Catalog in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: The DDF Catalog only executes at the privilege level of the Subject making the request. No elevation is possible.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: DDF Catalog may be able to impersonate the context of NSILI Source in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog runs on the same system as the NSILI Source.

threats.title: Spoofing of the External NSILI Client External Destination Entity
threats.description: External NSILI Service may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of External NSILI Service. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: The NSILI Source is used in an ad-hoc query fashion. Spoofing a remote system would not gain the attacker any access to data.

threats.title: External Entity External NSILI Client Potentially Denies Receiving Data
threats.description: External NSILI Service claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: Errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities.

threats.title: Data Flow Response Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: If the NSILI Source crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application

threats.title: Spoofing the External NSILI Client External Entity
threats.description: External NSILI Service may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to NSILI Source. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
threats.mitigation: The NSILI Source is only making query requests to the External NSILI Service. Only query parameters could be gained by spoofing the external service. The NSILI Source does not directly access data within the DDF catalog.

threats.title: Elevation Using Impersonation
threats.description: NSILI Source may be able to impersonate the context of External NSILI Service in order to gain additional privilege.
threats.mitigation: The NSILI Source is a trusted process/entity and will not attack the client(s). Authentication options are available for verification of legitimacy/identity.

threats.title: Spoofing the NSILI App Endpoint Process
threats.description: NSILI Source may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by External NSILI Service. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.
threats.mitigation: The NSIL interface assumes that servers and clients are installed on System High networks with network and workstation protections appropriate to the classification level of the network. It is assumed that all information loaded into an NSI library is authorized for access by all users authorized for the network.

threats.title: Potential Lack of Input Validation for NSILI Source
threats.description: Data flowing across Resource may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to a denial of service attack against NSILI Source or an elevation of privilege attack against NSILI Source or an information disclosure by NSILI Source. Failure to verify that input is as expected is a root cause of a very large number of exploitable issues. Consider all paths and the way they handle data. Verify that all input is verified for correctness using an approved list input validation approach.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including the NSILI Source.

threats.title: Potential Data Repudiation by NSILI App Endpoint
threats.description: NSILI Source claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
threats.mitigation: The NSILI Source is a trusted process/entity and errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities.

threats.title: Data Flow Sniffing
threats.description: Data flowing across Resource may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations. Consider encrypting the data flow.
threats.mitigation: HTTPS is available to encrypt the data flow.

threats.title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for NSILI App Endpoint
threats.description: NSILI Source crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
threats.mitigation: If the NSILI Source crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: Data Flow Request Is Potentially Interrupted
threats.description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
threats.mitigation: Errors and warnings are logged upon finding any irregularities. If the NSILI Source crashes, halts, or stops, the admin console can be used to start, stop, or restart the application.

threats.title: NSILI Source May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
threats.description: External NSILI Service may be able to remotely execute code for NSILI Source.
threats.mitigation: The route between the NSILI Source and the External NSILI Client should be trusted and network level protections should be in place.

threats.title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in NSILI Source
threats.description: An attacker may pass data into NSILI Source in order to change the flow of program execution within NSILI Source to the attacker's choosing.
threats.mitigation: DDF Catalog Framework performs input validation to guarantee sanitization for any endpoint including the NSILI Source.

threats.title: Cross Site Request Forgery
threats.description: Cross-site request forgery (CSRF or XSRF) is a type of attack in which an attacker forces a user's browser to make a forged request to a vulnerable site by exploiting an existing trust relationship between the browser and the vulnerable web site.  In a simple scenario, a user is logged in to web site A using a cookie as a credential.  The other browses to web site B.  Web site B returns a page with a hidden form that posts to web site A.  Since the browser will carry the user's cookie to web site A, web site B now can take any action on web site A, for example, adding an admin to an account.  The attack can be used to exploit any requests that the browser automatically authenticates, e.g. by session cookie, integrated authentication, IP whitelisting, â€¦  The attack can be carried out in many ways such as by luring the victim to a site under control of the attacker, getting the user to click a link in a phishing email, or hacking a reputable web site that the victim will visit. The issue can only be resolved on the server side by requiring that all authenticated state-changing requests include an additional piece of secret payload (canary or CSRF token) which is known only to the legitimate web site and the browser and which is protected in transit through SSL/TLS. See the Forgery Protection property on the flow stencil for a list of mitigations.
threats.mitigation: The NSILI App Endpoint always executes requests at the same privilege level so no additional data would be gained by forging another client's request.
